{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3149540,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-21T01:54:57.889Z","cooked":"

I’m seeking better answers for how to calculate the gear ratio for our arm. I know the 20:1 gearbox, but we have a chain reduction that is not intuitive.

We have a 10t sprocket, and at 40t sprocket, however the motor/10t sprocket are mounted on the arm, and the 40t sprocket is bolted to the upright post (and doesn’t turn).

The arm moves by the sprocket walking around the chain (which is ~58 links of #35 chain). The two sprocket are separated by ~6" (the 10t sprocket is 1.125" PD). My intuition was that the reduction would be 2*6" (the radius) / 1.125" = 10.6, but when I measure the angle the arm moves it moves ~90 degrees per rotation of the 10t sprocket (closer to 4:1 chain reduction).

Anyway, I welcome any useful explanation of the math.

I had more trouble finding a good picture but this should give an idea about it…this is an earlier version. The NEO/gearbox w/ 10t sprocket walks around the 40t (left) that is bolted to the upright.

401eef8849ee448ba0024dd3361daee6704×468 101 KB

It’s the same reduction as if both were normal sprockets… just a different configuration.

Time to fire up an older robot tonight, I acually have a motor-on-arm configuration in semi-running order. LMK if you want video of that to help.

That shouldn’t be necessary, but it just is not quite the answer I thought (but simple enough and confirmed by testing). Thanks for giving the correct solution, even it unravels what I thought I knew.

Here is the arm working as intended, and I don’t even have to change the 80:1 reduction that I put in after testing! https://photos.app.goo.gl/efNgNLdq2FHcdVqM6

You’ll get a kick about this one.

I checked the arm I had. 10:40 on the sprockets, plus some reduction in the motor pairing gearbox and each motor has its own gearbox. So I figured, even if you don’t need the video…

(And yes, that is an inspection sticker… from 2004. And yes, that is a 330 robot, despite the big sprocket not being yellow–the lift it’s on being blue is the giveaway there.)

Yeah, I did get a kick out of it. It is amazing looking at an old robot that is working (we have a lot of work in that department…someday!).

And I appreciate the prompt answer to my post.

Just think of it as the motor with the 10t sprocket is turning the whole world around its frame of reference, and it should be perfectly clear!
